title: Quiz 3: Fluid, Electrolytes & Acid-Base
description: Comprehensive assessment on fluid compartments, electrolyte imbalances (Na, K, Ca), and acid-base disorders.

questions.question: Match the electrolyte to its primary function:
questions.explanation: Sodium regulates volume; Potassium is critical for the heart; Calcium is for bones/clotting; Bicarbonate regulates pH.

questions.question: The normal range for serum Potassium is ___BLANK___ mEq/L.
questions.explanation: The normal potassium level is typically 3.5 to 5.0 mEq/L. Levels outside this range can cause dangerous arrhythmias.

questions.question: A patient presents with confusion, seizures, and a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. Which IV fluid is most indicated for severe, symptomatic treatment, but must be given cautiously?
questions.explanation: Severe hyponatremia with neurological symptoms requires Hypertonic Saline to raise sodium levels, but it must be done slowly to prevent brain damage.
questions.hint: To fix a 'low' concentration, you need a 'high' concentration fluid.

questions.question: Analyze the following ABG results: pH 7.25, PaCO2 55 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L.

richContent.content:
ParameterNormal RangePatient Value
pH7.35 - 7.457.25 (Acidosis)
PaCO235 - 4555 (High/Acidic)
HCO322 - 2824 (Normal)

questions.explanation: pH is low (Acidosis). CO2 is high (Respiratory cause). HCO3 is normal (No compensation yet). Diagnosis: Respiratory Acidosis.
questions.hint: Look at the CO2. It is high, which causes acid. The pH matches (acid).

questions.question: Which of the following ECG changes are associated with Hyperkalemia? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Hyperkalemia causes peaked T-waves and a widened QRS. U-waves and flattened T-waves are signs of Hypokalemia.

questions.question: Chvostek's sign and Trousseau's sign are clinical indications of Hypercalcemia.
questions.explanation: These are signs of HYPOcalcemia (low calcium), indicating neuromuscular irritability and tetany.
questions.hint: These signs show muscle twitching. Does high calcium or low calcium cause twitching?

questions.question: Match the IV fluid type to its effect on cells:

pairs.right: Water moves OUT of cells (Cells shrink)

questions.explanation: Hypo = low solute outside, water goes in. Hyper = high solute outside, water gets pulled out. Iso = equal.
questions.hint: Hypo makes cells like a hippo (fat/swell). Hyper makes them shrink.

questions.question: Which hormone is primarily responsible for retaining water in the body by acting on the kidneys?
questions.explanation: Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH) prevents diuresis (urination), causing the body to retain water.

questions.question: A patient has Metabolic Alkalosis. Which of the following is a common cause?
questions.explanation: Vomiting causes loss of stomach acid (HCl), leading to alkalosis. Diarrhea causes loss of base (bicarbonate), leading to acidosis.
questions.hint: Losing acid from the stomach makes the body alkaline.

questions.question: Order the compartments of body fluid from Largest Volume to Smallest Volume:
questions.explanation: ICF is ~2/3 of body water. ECF is ~1/3, of which Interstitial is the largest component, followed by Plasma, then Transcellular.
questions.hint: Most water is inside the cells.
